message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s behavior and speech suggest a brief psychotic disorder, which is characterized by a sudden onset of psychotic symptoms that last for less than a month. The negative urine drug screen also supports this diagnosis, ruling out drug-induced psychosis. The other options are personality disorders, which are not consistent with the acute onset of symptoms seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient displayed symptoms of a brief psychotic disorder, characterized by a sudden onset of psychotic symptoms such as delusions and/or hallucinations that last for a short period of time (less than one month) and are usually in response to significant stressors such as the death of a loved one. None of the personality disorders listed feature symptoms of acute psychosis. The negative urine drug screen rules out drug-induced psychosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The recent loss of her husband and the odd behavior suggest a brief psychotic disorder, which is characterized by an episode of psychotic symptoms lasting less than one month. The negative urine drug screen rules out drug-induced psychosis. The patient does not meet the criteria for schizoid, borderline, or schizotypal personality disorder as her symptoms are acute and brief, rather than chronic and pervasive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s behavior and speech suggest a brief psychotic disorder, which is defined as a sudden onset of at least one psychotic symptom, such as delusions or hallucinations, lasting from one day to one month. None of the other options fit the presentation of this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s sudden change in behavior, including delusions, is indicative of a psychotic episode. This, combined with the recent traumatic event of her husband’s death, suggests a diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder. None of the other personality disorders listed have symptoms consistent with this case, and the negative urine drug screen rules out drug-induced psychosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing delusions of grandeur, which is a symptom of a brief psychotic disorder. The negative results of the urine drug screen rule out drug-induced psychosis. None of the other options fit the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially the sudden onset of delusions and then sadness, suggest that she may be experiencing a brief psychotic disorder, which presents with sudden onset of at least one psychotic symptom that lasts no longer than a month. The results of the urine drug screen help rule out substance-induced psychotic disorder. None of the other personality disorders listed would explain this sudden and acute change in behavior.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible brief psychotic disorder, which is defined as the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms that lasts for a brief period of time (less than 1 month) and is usually triggered by a stressful life event such as the death of a loved one. The negative urine drug screen rules out substance-induced psychosis. Schizoid personality disorder, borderline personality disorder, and schizotypal personality disorder are all types of personality disorders that are characterized by longstanding patterns of behavior and thought, rather than a sudden onset of psychosis.

The negative drug screen helps rule out substance-induced psychosis. The other personality disorders listed do not fit the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s behavior and speech suggest a psychotic episode, and the recent death of her husband may have triggered it. The negative results of the urine drug screen rule out substance-induced psychotic disorder. The symptoms have been present for less than a month, making it a brief psychotic disorder. Schizoid, Borderline, and Schizotypal personality disorders have different characteristic symptoms that are not present in this case.
